Every time you do a pleasurable activity, this triggers a neurochemical responde where your brain releases dopamine , a hormone that makes us feel good ,the fact that determinates if you're extrovert or introvert is the sensitivity to this neurochemical and the amount of it that your brain releases, an introvert gets immersed on it's thoughts because they get a high level of dopamine from it , and they get overstimulated from social interaction because they release more dopamine than the amount they can handle , an extrovert is quite the opposite, even if an extrovert concentrates on it's own thoughts , the amount of dopamine they get is very low in comparison to an introvert, and when the brain craves dopamine it released a neuronal activity called "boredom " that is an unsatisfactory state where you crave stimulation, very similar to the codependency that an addict has to it's own addition, and every time an extrovert socialises with someone they trigger the same amount of dopamine that introverts release only by thinking, so yes, introverts never get bored due to high sensitivity to pleasure, and this factor plus their introspection is what allows introverts to spend more time upgrading their cognitive abilities,(extroverts are incapable of this because of their crave for stimulation resulting in distractions from the activity) leading me to the next phrase :
"A person that never gets bored can achieve anything "

Introverts are mostly in there head. That's why is so difficult to socialize and we tend to feel lack of energy. Because we need to use our energy for paying attention to what others have to say, Specially with people with other interests in a conversation. We just can't wait to finish talking so we could go home or someplace to be alone with our thoughts or projects. extroverts are  more expressive and feel uncomfortable with there inner thoughts they like to be heard. As an introvert I love solitude because it lets me create better with no distractions but I also recognized I use it to be protected from comments that coul compromise my sense of self. Words that could sabotage my inner dialogue in a bad way. I also recognize that when I am in a setting were I am with someone who shares the same interest as me or there is a boundary of respect between each other I feel more fluent with my words and even more out of my head. So i am guessing it's more a matter of connectiveness with the inner being rather than letting external circumstances determine you. Sometimes you will find yourself alone, other times people will be a round you, but you will still be the same person. It all depends on the setting you wish to be on.

Basically, IMO extroverts have it easier. But that’s just my opinion.

As someone who is very extroverted and am faring terribly during the pandemic (but there are way bigger issues out there) - just wanted to add my two cents:

I have very close introverted friends who are all very sweet and kind. There are many “introverts” out there who use it as an excuse to just be shitty people, eg “oh I made up an excuse not to go to this party like OMGAH” or somehow doing actual antisocial (not just asocial) things to seem cool. Nah, that’s just you being an asshole when someone plans a party and you back out three hours into the event because of “anxiety” (people who actually have social anxiety get hurt by you because you throw it around like a status symbol and trivialize their condition). That only adds negatively to some of the hate and pressure introverts get.

On the other hand, the dumb jock/party freak extroverts also exist, of course. Personally, I’ve seen way more extroverts who were more likely simply mildly inappropriate (dragging friends out to socialize) or being louder than acceptable, than to actually never think things through and jump off a bridge or something.

This whole forced distinction between introversion and extroversion is fun to think about, but I’d rather there be more understanding and tolerance - it’s a quick and easy tool to figure out how people would react and how to best achieve communication, but shouldn’t be used to just vilify every person of the “opposite” perspective. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

How did things get so mixed up? Every human being loses energy during human interaction. Including extroverts. If a human being were to actually GAIN energy during human interaction. It would be pretty rare.

The only difference between and introvert and an extrovert. Is that an introvert loses energy quicker then an extrovert does.

Being and introvert or an extrovert OR even an ambivert has nothing to do with how social you are, or what your good at.
It does have a pretty big influence.

What this means though, is that just because your an introvert, doesn’t mean you aren’t social or you like to stay at home all day. And being an extrovert doesn’t mean you just want to talk to people and party all the time! In fact, it could be the exact opposite.

This is to all those who do not believe 'ambiverts' exist. Yes, it seems quite unlikely but I'd like to elaborate on the ambivert section as it is not provided in the video. I would call myself an ambivert, why? Well, first I'm not someone who likes to avoid social interaction (I'm not saying its bad to do so). Neither do I love to be in the spotlight 24/7, so I'm selectively social. I avoid interactions when I don not feel like taking part in them, not because I'm shy to be judged or so. I'm not awkward, I can keep up conversations (and quite frankly I have lots of friends and acquaintances) but I only keep few (2-3) very close. I'm very confident while speaking in public and expressing my opinions (those are the times where I'd love to be in the spotlight) However, there are moments where I just want to shut down, hole up in my apartment to read a book. So, I'm not at the either end of the scale. Somewhere in between. Also, I'd like to mention, I was more extroverted than I am now (I'm more on the introvert side) I think I can shift, where I am uneasy to talk to anyone or when I get social sprees where I make a target to make new friends or to improve friendships. But, yeah I think ambivert actually exist.
(If you think I'm either of them, please leave a comment below. I'd like to know If i am wrong)

Introversion literally just means that after spending time with other people, you need some time to yourself to 'recharge' almost - you can enjoy a social event and be an introvert. It just means that after a while, once you reach your limit, you start to feel tired and/or bored. Doesn't mean you don't like extreme sports or that you're quiet and uncomfortable in social situations.

Extrovertion means that you gather energy from being around other people. You guys are usually the most reluctant to leave a party early because you just don't feel like you want to leave yet. It doesn't mean that you don't need alone time or a lazy day. And it doesn't mean that you can't enjoy a good book or a quiet walk in the park.

I don't think people quite understand what ambiversion is because I've been reading a few comments that say things along the lines of 'I can be super talkative but sometimes I just need to be alone' THAT'S introversion. Introversion is when you are drained by stimulation, no matter how much you enjoy it or do it. You can be an extremely sociable person and still be introverted because you are simply drained after a long while with large amounts of people. Extraversion is when you gain more energy and thrill from being with others and function at your best in stimulation. Being alone and doing little drains you, no matter how much you enjoy it. Ambiversion is when you are able to function extremely well in lots of stimulation or very little stimulation. You dont only get drained by one or the other, either. Then again, I haven't looked into ambiversion as much, so what do I know? I'm only super passionate about subjects like these. Sidenote: isn't it cool that at least 1 in 3 people we know are introverts? Sorry I just find it facinating!!

I usually like to define Introversion vs Extroversion by how you primarily gain your energy: with extroverts gaining energy from time with people, and introverts needing time alone to regain energy.  I also see it as a sliding scale where no one is completely one or the orher. Most Ambiverts, I feel, are simply near the middle. They may simply be very outgoing Introverts with a bigger social battery, or laid back Extroverts who take more than the typical amount of alone time. The term Ambivert doesn't seem applicable to me, because it makes these people sound like some kind of third personality, while I would argue they are the same.

Full introvert, freshman in high school, got a crush two months ago, thick introvert shell in back to take bullying, thin, vulnerable front for love related stuff. I planned out telling her how I felt on Monday at lunch on a Saturday. I rehearsed every outcome possible (I thought) Monday comes, I walk towards her table. I see her friends encouraging her towards something she's nervous about, I'm confused. She tells a guy (I didn't ever really even like this guy) that she likes him, they start going out. Front is shattered, back is thinned, I'm extra vulnerable for the next week, I take everything seriously. I shut myself off, I talk to nobody unless necessary, not even my friends, always listen to music, in order to shut myself off from conversations. I retreated into what was left of my shell to avoid getting hurt like this ever again. Front never healed, back is fine now. I'm still in my shell after two weeks, and I haven't talked to her much after it. I still beat myself up inside sometimes over it whenever I see them together. DEPRESSION! YAAAAAAAAAY!!!!

Fascinating video; I'm an introvert, and quite proud of it.  Though I'm able to socialize with people if need be, I'm much more comfortable in the presence of a few good friends, I'm quiet, I like to plan, and my ideal night of fun is one spent at home on the internet or with my art and writing (or with a D&D group if I could ever find one x3).  Incidentally, I'd heard the difference between introverts and extroverts as having to do with energy; mental, spiritual, whathaveyou or whatbelieveyou, as well: Extroverts like to be around people because they need the energy and attention and thrive off of it, whereas Introverts create their own energy and only like to share it with people they trust or feel they can respect.  However you go about it, I believe neither personality is better.  Extrovert or Introvert, if you feel you're alright living how you live, then that's all you need. =)

I enjoy public speaking (with some anxiety) but I am scared as heck when at auditions for something.
I have been advancing in my grades very well and I do not exactly have a happy response to a 100 on a test. My shy side uncovers and I can be kind of embarrassed when faced with an accomplishment.

Sooo, yeah.

I was an introvert from birth through age 15. From age 16 through 21 I was an extreme extrovert and engaged in constant socialization, wilderness adventures, wild parties and raves, and generally lived and thrived on the fringe of society. At age 21 I was struck by a car while riding my bicycle home from a friend's house. My left temporal bone in my skull was fractured severely and I suffered a traumatic brain injury (TBI) in my left temporal lobe, which is the speech, communication, and language center of the brain as far as scientists currently know. From age 21 through today I slowly became more introverted and now I am happiest when I spend the majority of my time alone in quiet study, creating art and music as well as writing creative, analytical, and scientific essays. I still need some social time, but my need for socialization is minimal these days. I now become socially exhausted after spending more than 24 hours with friends or extended family. I need a long period of "decompression" or relaxation time to recover from social events. Overall, I believe my personality exists somewhere on the left side of the middle of the spectrum where far left is strong introversion, middle is ambiversion, and far right is strong extroversion. Ultimately, it is clear now that personality type shifts dramatically over the lifespan. However, it is probable that some people shift more than others. Great video by the way! Thanks for making all of your wonderful content @AsapSCIENCE :)

The thing is that all personality traits are continuous scales. There are a few ways to break people into being "introverts" or "extraverts" (mean-splitting, quartile bins, etc.), but that removes the ability to say that one person is more or less introverted than another. That's why the "ambivert" label is so silly; it's not that you're a mix of both, or the best of both, it's just that you don't score highly in either direction.
Also, the extra allele copy relating to adventure is more likely to be linked to the Openness to Experiences dimension than to Introversion/Extraversion.
"Extraversion was the factor most strongly associated with leadership. It is the most important trait of effective leaders" (Judge, Bono, Ilies, and Gerhardt, 2002).

I feel like a lot of people are saying that they're an ambivert in the comment section, and considering ambiverts are meant to be rare, it'd be weird if literally the majority of comments claim that they're ambiverts. A lot of people probably think they are because they might not fully identify with one of either of the two personality types. Carl Jung even said himself that it's rare to have someone be 100% on one side of the spectrum. The stuff they mentioned in the video doesn't determine your type (so if you like doing both introverted and extroverted activities, it doesn't mean anything), but it's kind of like Extrovert and Introvert tendencies. I would usually just say that if you're an introvert, you like spending time by yourself (it doesn't matter how loud or gregarious you are) and draw energy from being by yourself, and if your an extrovert you prefer being around people (even if you are socially awkward or quiet). That's the simplest way to put it and it doesn't over complicate things.

Introverted politicians are at a huge disadvantage because we like to take our time and think through things, and that's something you can't do in a debate or a town-hall meeting or just generally out there on the campaign trail. And and answer like "That's a good question. Let me think on that a while and get back to you." is seen as dodging the question instead of being seen as a mature, logical and reasonable response to a question one might not have an immediate answer for. Also with the amount of fund raising that politicians have to do, it's going to wear out introverts and cause them to not seek reelection more often than it would for extraverts, so the people who would be best suited to sitting back in their office on the weekend reading through the bills being proposed are the ones who are less likely to enter politics in general.

The way I understand Myers/Briggs/Jung is that we exist with a "range" of traits, seldom exclusively introvert or extrovert. Under some circumstances we may act or behave toward the extrovert side. Other times and circumstances we may lean more toward introvert. It is possible to be closer to the center of this scale and possibly we can exist strongly toward introvert or extrovert. Everyone is different and we may actually change our traits and move toward either end of the scale depending upon our experiences and age. There is nothing to suggest that one set of traits is better or worse than any other traits. We are what we are. I'm not sure if Myers/Briggs or Jung suggests introvert/extrovert has any correlation to intelligence since intelligence may change with age, education and experiences.

I like this video. As someone who knows quite a bit of intro- and extroverted people, I grow kind of tired of hearing them break each other down. Introverted friends often say how intelligent and creative they are and how dumb extroverted people are (in their opinion). Extroverted people are often pictured as loud, speak-before-you-think, blabbing arrogant people who live life without any sense of sensitivity or intellectual thoughts. I agree that society is built to appreciate extroverted people more, and this sucks. But I feel like introverted people's reaction to this is often to reduce extroverted people to 'idiots' to try so they can make themselves feel better about being introverted. Extroverted people can be incredibly sensitive and insecure. They just get their energy from different things (like hanging out with many friends), but at the end of the day they are just as human as introverted people. The dislike works both ways by the way. Extroverted people sometimes think all introverted people hate interacting with others, when really they just don't like big crowds. Not only because it makes them feel stressed or uncomfortable, but also because it's just not interesting or fun to them and they'd rather have a deeper conversation with one person they like. I think there is such a thing as intro- and extroversion, but A) I believe they are situated on two sides of a spectrum and there is such a thing as people who are neither (somewhat in between, like ambivert) and B) I don't think either one is better than the other. It's wonderful that there are so many different people out there, it's what makes this world so interesting. I consider myself an ambivert, but anyone is welcome in my club. Rant over :)

I probably would fit the bill of an ambivert.. or bipolar? For example, sometimes I look forward to going to school, can walk confidently, and can talk to the prettiest girl in school with ease. Then, out of nowhere, sometimes even mid-conversation, all that positive energy just flees in an instant. Leaving me feeling self conscious, hopeless, and at a loss for words. Whenever that happens, my whole day just becomes a depressing blur that passes by in a flash. What's even stranger is that this emotion actually has a heavy feeling to it, particularly felt in my chest. Well, this feeling persists for the rest of the day until I find myself back home, staring at the ceiling in contemplation about what the hell happened. Oddly enough, I feel super calm and collected whilst contemplating this. Oftentimes wishing that that moment of fleeting bliss would last the rest of my life, and dreading what emotions the next day will hold. Sometimes I find myself in tears for no apparent reason after an episode of this has gone by... Unfortunately, this is how the majority of my highschool life has been since freshman year (I'm now a Senior). I haven't always been like this. I used to be a class clown and be the most talkative one in my class. Now I can go a whole day in bitter, depressing silence, dreading my emotions of tomorrow, but can end up feeling absolutely unconquerable when tomorrow arrives.
AMBIVERTS UNITE

I agree with everything in this video, except I don't think extroversion necessarily relates to stupidity and brashness and neither do introversion. Why do we have to pick sides? I am done with people assuming that extroversion equals stupidity and introversion means intelligence. It works both ways. You can be an extrovert and be stupid, and an introvert and be stupid. Isn't extroversion just interacting with your external environment more often then your internal?

And what do people mean by intelligence? They say extroverts take things by face value but they're also looking at extroversion and assuming their intelligence based off of their preference. You can be an extrovert and be incredibly "smart", and an introvert and be incredibly "smart". Why are parties suddenly a toxic environment and full of drunk idiots? why is reading at home considered being a shut-in and anxiety ridden?

On the other side of the spectrum, using the same example, why are people at parties that talk a lot considered shallow and horrible? Why is reading considered being a genius? Extroverts can be painters and writers, introverts can be sociable and friendly (of course with much needed recharge time).

I'm not disregarding those who have genuine problems with interactions and anxiety, but I'm just upset with all this stereotypical backlash against both sides.

(If you've read this far, congrats omigosh XDD i went on a rant lol. Have a wonderful day~)

Okay so this my gripe with the whole extrovert(X)/introvert(Y) labeling. You see, if I label myself as X or Y, my behavior will follow that of which I see myself as. So if I am an X is will behave as X because I identify as X, even if I am not X whole heartedly. Thus in the video it says Ambiverts tend to be in the middle, which to me is the best choice (and yes I do think being an extrovert or introvert to be a choice mixed with childhood interactions... for example if you were in plays as a child then public speaking is no issue or less scary etc). So when it comes to being X or Y, choose the middle ground since its the most flexible one and it doesn't tie your identity to one extreme.

Introvert.
Worst Parts:
- Going out to eat takes at least 30 minutes to an hour (if it's somewhere you have never been before) of mental preparation. Just the thought of being in public stirs the anxiety within me.
- Anxiety. My brain is constantly asking "what if" questions and running through as many scenarios as it can before the action takes place. I never have peace of mind until I can mentally guarantee everything is going to be alright (or at least bearable).
- Participation Points. Ever had a class that gives you points based on your participation? Yeah, I hate it too. It's not that I have nothing to say, I just hate how unnatural it feels to speak out on demand.
- Invisible in a group. If there's a group bigger than 3 or 4 I will almost never talk unless I know 95% of the people there. The only other reason I feel the need to talk is if it's something very interesting or if it's something I believe contributes positively to the conversation. My mind is usually too busy studying other people and what they have to say.
- Indecisiveness. It's hard for me to decide things because I get fixated on the pros and cons. The less cons the harder it is to decide.

P.S. Let me just add that breaking humans into only 2 or even 3 groups is unrealistic and is not a viable method of categorizing.

I think they are like sides to a coin. You need A to balance out B. I think both are equal because both have negatives and positives. Having an introvert and an extrovert debating generally leads to the best 'in-between' idea, I think. As an ambivert I'm quite good at using other people's ideas from both sides and mediate them into something less extreme to one side, or more 'global'. Often even practical.
Especially extroverts tend to come up to me with ideas that aren't very practical, where as introverts often come up with ideas that are well thought-through, but often lack a kind of 'personal touch' which would turn a lot of people off at the idea.

So, having both = best of both worlds, as long as both have learned to accept other people's opinions and aren't stubborn d-bags.

I'm an Introvert (an actual introvert, not an ambivert that just thinks they're an introvert, as many are). Over the years that I've been aware of the two types of personalities, I've noticed how society almost thinks there's something wrong with introverts, and that it's their job to turn these introverts into extraverts (which is not really possible). Society is poorly or incorrectly educated about introverts.

As I've looked at colleges recently, I've noticed that many seem to think that if your not a sociable extravert, you're not good enough. Though I could join a club that I'm genuinely interested in, most clubs colleges recognize and like are things such as debate club, student government representatives, etc. I'm the type of person who doesn't care much for the clubs provided, partially because I don't really care to be in a club, and partially because the things I like to do (3D animation and app coding) are individual things. I don't do sports or participate in clubs, but that doesn't mean I'm a deadbeat. I've worked on many big projects on my own, and am even coding my own app for the App Store. Sad thing is, many colleges don't ask about these personal projects, they only care that I'm social.

I'm a huge Jungian fan and I'd like to add that personality traits should not be black and white, but more of a blend of everything. That being said, the concluding question should be more so how much percentage are you introverted/extroverted rather than forcing the audience to select only 1 trait. That way ambiverts would be those who have ~50% of each trait while others would have levels ranging from mild to strong introversion/extroversion. Instructing others that they can only be one trait creates ignorance and paints a bad image on Jungian theory.

I'm an introvert myself, and here's a little story:
Back when I was in kindergarten, I remember telling my mom that the other kids always annoy me. In turned out, they just wanted to play with me, but I simply prefered playing alone.

Eysenck developed the extraversion scale, which suggests that we are not 'ambiverts', rather we fall somewhere on the spectrum of extraversion.  I think it's confusing to state that a person falls into one of three groups (extraverts, introverts, or ambiverts) because it gives the impression that variation within these groups does not exist and that all people in one group are about the same.  If we instead only refer to the spectrum, it becomes apparent that there is a lot of variation in the human population and that introversion and extraversion manifests differently in different people.

so early here,have some cake 😁😁 ingredients
1 cup Choc Ripple biscuit crumbs
1/2 cup castor sugar
1/2 cup thickened cream
1/4 cup ground almonds
200g Toblerone milk or dark chocolate for shaving
200g Toblerone milk or dark chocolate, melted
500g cream cheese, sofftened
80g butter, melted

method
Combine biscuit crumbs, melted butter and almonds and press into the base of a lightly greased springform tin.
Using an electric mixer beat the cream cheese and sugar until all of the sugar is dissolved. Add the thickened cream and beat in the melted chocolate until well combined. Pour into the springform tin on top of the biscuit crumb.
Grate Toblerone shavings over the top and refrigerate for 2-3 hours until set.
